{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Homestead Sports Complex | nickname = | image = | fullname = Homestead Sports Complex | address = 1601 SE 28th Ave, Homestead, FL 33035 | location = [[Homestead, FL]] | coordinates = {{coord|25.45161|-80.43095|display=inline,title|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = 1991 | built = 1991 & 1993 | opened = | owner = [[Homestead, Florida|City of Homestead]] | renovated = | operator = | architect = Populous | structural engineer =Bliss & Nyitray, Inc | surface = Grass | former_names = | tenants = Vacant | seating_capacity = Baseball - 6,500 | dimensions = Left Field: 322ft
Center Field: 400ft
Right Field: 322ft }} '''Homestead Sports Complex''' is a [[baseball]] training facility located less than three miles from downtown [[Homestead, Florida|Homestead]], [[Florida]]. The facility seats 6,500 and expands to 9,000, and provides parking for over 3,900 vehicles. A 200-bed dormitory facility located on the grounds of the Homestead Sports Complex complements the training facilities. The dormitories consist of 30 single rooms and 84 double rooms that are complete with restrooms, showers, dressing areas, a full service kitchen and recreational areas. ==History== In 1991 the [[City of Homestead]] built the Sports Complex at a price tag of $22 million in order to provide a [[spring training]] facility for the [[Cleveland Indians]]. The stadium was widely recognized as being state-of-the-art for the time period, as it included multiple practice facilities as well as dormitories for players. The Indians had previously played in the [[Cactus League]] in Arizona but had signed a deal to make Homestead their long-term spring training home. Cleveland was due to begin full-time play at the stadium in the 1993 season. In 1992 they had already begun moving equipment and personnel to Florida. However, on August 24, 1992, [[Hurricane Andrew]] made landfall in Homestead as a Category 5 [[cyclone]] with winds reaching 165 mph. The stadium, directly in the path of the hurricane, was decimated. The Indians quickly began meetings with lawyers and eventually they exercised an "out clause" in the contract. The city decided to immediately re-construct the stadium hoping that they could have it built for the 1994 spring training season in order for the Indians, or perhaps another team to use. However, without a spring facility for the 1993 season Cleveland was forced to look quickly for another home. The [[Boston Red Sox]] were leaving [[Winter Haven, Florida]]'s [[Chain of Lakes Park]] after 26 years, allowing the Indians to use Chain of Lakes as their spring facility. However, knowing the situation that the Indians were in, Winter Haven allowed the team to use the stadium on the condition that they sign a 10-year contract. Cleveland had no other choice, so they signed the deal and left Homestead without a team. Homestead decided to continue re-building the stadium, assuming that at some point in the future they could lure another team to use it as their spring facility. The stadium was re-constructed in a very short period of time, as the original blueprints were kept. However, after about five years without a tenant it started to appear that the facility may never be used as a home for baseball. In the meantime, new spring training facilities were constructed such as [[Roger Dean Stadium]] in [[Jupiter, Florida]] and [[Champion Stadium]] at [[Walt Disney World]]. The new stadiums began to surpass Homestead Sports Complex in terms of facility size and technology. The city had to look at other options in order to pay the nearly $450,000 per year in order to maintain it. It was offered as a home for the [[US Soccer Federation]] to conduct its training, but they declined. In 1999 the facility was used as part of the filming of the [[Oliver Stone]] movie ''[[Any Given Sunday]]''. In 2002 an [[HBO]] series called ''Baseball Wives'' was to be primarily filmed at the stadium, but the show was canceled before ever getting off the ground. In 2004, it served as the home of the [[Florida Thunder]], the city's [[Pro Cricket]] team. The facility hosted local youth and adult sports on the training grounds but the internal workings of the stadium such as bathrooms, electrical and plumbing had gone into disrepair. The park was used for the City of Homestead's [[Fourth of July]] celebration until the [[Homestead-Miami Speedway]] took over the duties in 2010, attracting an exponentially larger crowd than ever before. The facility was damaged again by 2017's [[Hurricane Irma]].{{cite news |last1=Reichard |first1=Kevin |title=Homestead Sports Complex Slated for Scrap Heap |url=https://ballparkdigest.com/2018/07/01/homestead-sports-complex-slated-for-scrap-heap/ |accessdate=July 5, 2018 |work=Ballpark Digest |publisher=August Publications |date=July 1, 2018}} ==Future== After Hurricane Irma, the City Commission requested a feasibility study on the complex. Five of the six options in the study involve tearing down the ball park. The city solicited demolition bids. A final decision is pending. ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.cityofhomestead.com/pages/recreation/park-facilities.aspx City of Homestead page] *[http://www.digitalballparks.com/Florida/Homestead.html Photo Gallery of Stadium] {{Homestead, Florida}} [[Category:Cricket grounds in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Florida]] [[Category:Homestead, Florida]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1991]] [[Category:Cricket in Florida]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2017}} {{Underlinked|date=June 2016}} }}
'''Jetboard''' in [[Hydroflight sports|Hydroflight Sports]] is a device that uses water propulsion as its means of flying above the surface of any body of water.
In jetboarding the athlete is standing in wakeboard-style boots/bindings which are attached to a board or independent base plates with jets extending downward from under the feet.<ref>http://worldhydroflightassociation.org/</ref>
The aim in jetboarding is to perform tricks such as dolphin dives, spins and backflips (even multiples), and combinations of two or more tricks.
Competitive jetboarding began in 2012 with the first Flyboard World Cup, a freestyle trick jetboard competition in which athletes are critiqued by a panel of judges.<ref>http://www.h2romagazine.com/hydroflight-sports</ref>
The world’s first open competitive event for hydroflight jetboards, Session One, was held at LTS Training school in Pompano Beach Florida on February 13-14th, 2016.<ref>http://www.x-jetpacks.com/session-one-overview/</ref>
List of boards and manufacturers in alphabetical order: * [http://www.dolphin-board.com Dolphin Board] * [http://zapata-racing.com/fr/ Flyboard] * [http://www.x-jetpacks.com X-Jets Jetblade] * [http://defywaterflight.com Defy Jetdeck] * [https://www.flydive.com Flydive X-Board]
==References== {{reflist}} http://www.jetboard.com/
http://www.jetsurf-france.fr/
http://www.powerski.com/content/psi_index.php

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} [[File:David Performs a Grab at Capital Bocking USA.png|thumb|right|upright|A man performs a grab at the Capital Bocking USA Meetup.]] [[File:Powerboker.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A powerbocker]] [[File:A Pair of M60 Powerizers.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A pair of M60 Powerizers]] [[File:Powerskip Standard.jpg|thumb|upright|A pair of Powerskips]]
'''Jumping stilts''' or '''spring stilts''' are special [[stilts]] that allow the user to run, jump and perform various acrobatics. Spring stilts using fiberglass leaf springs were patented in the United States in 2004 under the trademark "PowerSkip", marketed for recreational and extreme sports use.<ref>Alexander Böck (13 April 2004) {{US Patent|6719671}} "Device for helping a person to walk".</ref> Spring stilts are often mostly made of [[aluminium]]. Using these stilts is also called "bocking" or "powerbocking", a corrupted version of the name of the stilts' inventor, Alexander Boeck.
==Powerbocking== The act of "bocking" or "powerbocking" includes jumping, running, and performing acrobatics with elastic-like [[Spring (device)|spring]]-loaded [[stilts]].<ref name=Hom>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/26/AR2007102602492.html|title=A Giant Step for Mankind|publisher=The Washington Post | date=30 October 2007 | accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref> For some it is an [[extreme sport]]; for others it is a form of exercise or even artistic expression.
The stilts are often referred to generically as bocks or powerbocks; as power stilts, jumping stilts, or spring stilts; or by their brand name.
==Description== Each boot consists of a foot-plate with [[snowboard]] type bindings, rubber foot pad which is also commonly called a hoof, and a [[fibreglass]] [[leaf spring]]. Using only their weight, and few movements, the user is generally able to [[jumping|jump]] 3–5 ft (1–1.5 metres) off the ground and [[running|run]] up to 20 mph (32 km/h). They also give the ability to take up to 9-foot (2.7 metres) strides.<ref name=Zebedee>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/health/dietfitness.html?in_article_id=420612|title=Zebedee Workout|publisher=Daily Mail | location=London | date=5 December 2006}}</ref>
Jumping stilts were used in the closing ceremony of the 2008 Olympic games in Beijing.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U2bEAz2cpD8|title=Beijing 2008 Olympic Video}}</ref>
==Brands== They were originally patented by Alexander Böck, from Germany (European Patent EP 1 196 220 B1 on 2 July 2003, US Patent No. 6,719,671 B1 on 13 April 2004, both with a priority date of 20 July 1999), as "Powerskip". Many people also use common brand names to refer to them generically.<ref>See introduction on the forum: [http://www.poweriserpages.com PoweriserPages.com]</ref> Common brand names are 7 League Boots, Air-Trekkers, Powerizers, Pro-Jump, and Powerskips.
==Risks== On 4 December 2010 Samuel Koch was heavily injured during the show ''[[Wetten, dass..?]]'' during a stunt where he attempted to jump over multiple moving cars in succession. He failed to clear one of the moving vehicles and was left [[tetraplegia|tetraplegic]] after suffering severe injuries to his neck and spine.
== Competition == Two competitions exist in France: the Nancy Power Days (since 2009) at Nancy<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.clubeasyrisernancy.com/single-post/2016/05/05/NANCY-POWER-DAYS-2016|title=NANCY-POWER-DAYS-2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=10 February 2017}}</ref> and the Riser Winter Cup (since 2015) at Lille.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://riser-road.fr/wintercup/index.php/fr/|title=Riser Winter Cup|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=10 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CGj21_X1zUg|title=Riser Winter Cup 2017 Trailer|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=10 February 2017}}</ref>
==Similar devices== Though similar in appearance, powerbocking is not to be confused with the use of [[Mechanics of Oscar Pistorius' running blades|prosthetic devices]] such as those used by paralympic runner [[Oscar Pistorius]].
[[Moon shoes]] and [[Kangoo Jumps]] are earlier attempts at '''jumping shoes''' using a different technique. Some are still popular today. [[Rocket boots]] were designed in the 1970s for the Russian Army, and use combustion pistons rather than springs for a similar effect.
Similar devices are attached to the boots of [[Chell (Portal)|Chell]] (the protagonist) in the ''[[Portal (video game)|Portal]]'' video game series for the purpose of surviving long falls, though such devices might not actually work in real life.
An English folklore figure, [[spring-heeled Jack]], has been conjectured by some investigators to have been a prankster using spring-loaded leaping aids as early as 1837.
Spring stilts using steel coil springs, an antecedent of the [[pogo stick]], were attempted in the 19th century.<ref>George H. Heerington (22 February 1881) {{US Patent|238042}} "Spring-stilt"</ref><ref>Nicholas Yagn (21 October 1890) {{US Patent|438830}} "Apparatus for facilitating walking"</ref>

{{Infobox horseraces | class = Grade III | horse race = Monmouth Oaks | image = | caption = | location = [[Monmouth Park Racetrack]]
[[Oceanport, New Jersey]], [[United States|USA]] | inaugurated = 1871 | race type = [[Thoroughbred]] - [[Flat racing]] | website = {{URL|1=http://www.monmouthpark.com/haskell/pastwinners.asp?pwid=39}} | distance = {{frac|1|1|16}} miles | surface = Dirt | track = left-handed | qualification = Three-year-old [[filly|fillies]] | weight = 122 lbs., allowances to 6 lbs. for non winners | purse = $100,000 (2015) | bonuses = }} The '''Monmouth Oaks''' is an [[United States|American]] [[Thoroughbred horse race]] held annually at [[Monmouth Park Racetrack]] in [[Oceanport, New Jersey]] for three-year-old [[filly|fillies]]. Named for [[England|England's]] [[Epsom Oaks]], first run in 1779, the inaugural American edition took place in 1871. Originally raced over a distance of {{frac|1|1|2}} miles from 1871 through 1877, there was no race in 1878 but on its return the following year was modified to {{frac|1|1|4}} miles. In 1891, the [[New Jersey Legislature]] began a move to ban [[parimutuel betting]] and the Oaks had to be moved to the [[Jerome Park Racetrack]] in [[The Bronx]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. With a legislated permanent ban, after the 1893 running the Monmouth Park Racetrack was shut down and the property sold. years. In 1946, Thoroughbred racing returned to a new Monmouth Park racing facility. The revived Monmouth Oaks was set at {{frac|1|1|16}} miles and in 1997 [[Blushing K. D.]] set the existing record for that distance at 1:41.80. Over the years, the Oaks has been won by some of the best fillies in the United States including [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|U.S. Racing Hall of Fame]] inductees, [[Miss Woodford]] (1883), [[Firenze (horse)|Firenze]] (1887), [[Dark Mirage]] (1968), [[Gallant Bloom]] (1969) and [[Desert Vixen]] (1973). It is currently a [[Graded stakes race|Grade III]] stakes race with a [[Purse distribution|purse]] of $100,000 divided 60% to the winning owner, 20% to second, 11% to third, 6% to fourth and 3% to fifth. There was no race held in 2003. ==Winners of the Monmouth Oaks== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="background-color:#DACAA5; width:25px" | Year

The '''National Football Foundation''' ('''NFF''') is a [[non-profit organization]] founded in 1947 with early leadership from [[General Douglas MacArthur]], longtime [[Army Black Knights football]] coach [[Earl Blaik]] and journalist [[Grantland Rice]]. Its mission is to promote and develop amateur [[American football]] on all levels throughout the United States and to cultivate leadership, sportsmanship, enthusiasm for competition, and the drive for academic excellence among America's youth.
In addition to supporting amateur football on the local level, the National Football Foundation also oversees the support, administration, and operation of the [[College Football Hall of Fame]]. Among its other programs and initiatives includes the facilitation of the Play It Smart program, which places a trained "academic coach" who turns football teams into learning teams in underserved high schools across the country, and the awarding of the [[William V. Campbell Trophy]] presented by [[HealthSouth Corporation]], referred to in many circles as the "Academic Heisman". In spring 2007, the NFF launched the NFF Hampshire Honor Society, a recognition program for players who excel both on the field and in the classroom. Inductees must have been a starter in their final collegiate season and have earned a 3.2 cumulative [[grade point average|GPA]] for their undergraduate degree.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.footballfoundation.com/news.php?id=1143 |title=NFF Announces Inaugural National Honor Society |publisher=National Football Foundation |date=2007-04-25 |accessdate=2007-07-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070821072136/http://www.footballfoundation.com/news.php?id=1143 |archivedate=2007-08-21 |df= }}</ref> The Foundation also tabulated and released the Bowl Championship Series Standings each Fall and hosts an Annual Awards Dinner in December at the [[Waldorf-Astoria]] in [[New York City]].
[[Archie Manning]], a former [[Ole Miss Rebels football]] [[All-American]] and member of the College Football Hall of Fame, serves as the current chairman,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://footballfoundation.org/sports/2018/7/27/nff-officers.aspx|title=NFF Officers|website=footballfoundation.org}}</ref> and [[Steven J. Hatchell]], the former commissioner of the [[Big 12 Conference]] and executive director of the [[FedEx Orange Bowl]], serves as its current president. The foundation has 120 local chapters distributed among 48 states. Since 1956, more than 100,000 volunteers have become members.
== National Scholar-Athlete Awards == Founded in 1959, the award is presented each season to the nation's top scholar-athletes for excellence in academics, athletics and leadership. Fifteen to seventeen scholar-athletes are chosen from the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] Divisions [[NCAA Division I|I]] (both [[Football Bowl Subdivision|I-A/FBS]] and [[Football Championship Subdivision|I-AA/FCS]]), [[NCAA Division II|II]] and [[NCAA Division III|III]] and the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] and awarded a $18,000 scholarship. One of the recipients is chosen and awarded the [[William V. Campbell Trophy]] (formerly the Draddy Trophy).<ref>{{cite web|title=The William V. Campbell Trophy|url=https://footballfoundation.org/sports/2018/7/31/the-william-v-campbell-trophy.aspx|publisher=footballfoundation.org}}</ref>
Notable former National Scholar-Athletes in the NFL include [[Ryan Tannehill]] ([[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M]], 2011)<ref>{{cite news|title=Tuesday's Chalktalk |url=https://footballfoundation.org/news/2011/12/27/_51323.aspx?path=football|publisher=footballfoundation.org|date=December 27, 2011}}</ref> and [[Joe Thomas (American football)|Joe Thomas]] ([[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin]], 2006)<ref>{{cite news|title= TUESDAY’S CHALKTALK|url=https://footballfoundation.org/news/2013/1/22/_53107.aspx?path=football|publisher=footballfoundation.org|date=January 22, 2013}}</ref> and [[Super Bowl]] winners [[Peyton Manning|Peyton]] ([[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]], 1997) and [[Eli Manning]] ([[Ole Miss Rebels football|Mississippi]], 2003), [[Drew Brees]] ([[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]], 2000), [[Jonathan Vilma]] ([[Miami Hurricanes football|Miami]], 2003)<ref>{{cite news|title=Jonathan Vilma|url=https://footballfoundation.org/hof_scholars.aspx?hof=135|work=NFF National Scholar-Athletes|publisher=footballfoundation.org}}</ref> and [[Dennis Dixon]] ([[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon]], 2007). Non-sporting former recipients include [[Emmy Awards|Emmy]] and [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe]]-nominated actor [[Mark Harmon]] ([[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]]), [[NASA]] astronaut and [[United States Air Force|USAF]] [[flight test engineer]] [[Michael S. Hopkins]] ([[Illinois Fighting Illini football|Illinois]]), former USAF pilot and incumbent [[Hampden–Sydney College]] President [[Christopher B. Howard]] ([[Air Force Falcons football|U.S. Air Force Academy]])<ref>{{cite news|title=Chris Howard|work=NFF National Scholar-Athletes|url=https://footballfoundation.org/hof_scholars.aspx?hof=36|publisher=footballfoundation.org}}</ref> and [[NBC]] anchor [[Stone Phillips]] ([[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale]]).<ref>{{cite news|title=NFF National Scholar-Athlete Class Prepares for the NFL Draft|url=https://footballfoundation.org/news/2014/5/6/_54763.aspx?path=football|publisher=footballfoundation.org|date=May 6, 2014}}</ref>
== National Football Foundation Gold Medal == {{main|National Football Foundation Gold Medal Winners}} The Gold Medal, the NFF’s highest honor, has been presented to seven U.S. Presidents, four U.S. Generals, three U.S. Admirals, one U.S. Supreme Court Justice, 25 Corporate CEOs and Chairmen.
== Distinguished American Award == {{main|National Football Foundation Distinguished American Award}} Presented on special occasions when a truly deserving individual emerges, the award honors someone who has applied the character building attributes learned from amateur sport in their business and personal life, exhibiting superior leadership qualities in education, amateur athletics, business and in the community.
==MacArthur Bowl== {{main|MacArthur Bowl}} Every year, the National Football Foundation awards the [[MacArthur Bowl]] to the NCAA Division I-FBS college football team determined to be the national champion.
==John L. Toner Award== {{see also|National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics #Awards}} The annual award is given to an [[athletic director]] who has demonstrated superior administrative abilities and shown outstanding dedication to college athletics and particularly college football.
''Note: * = posthumously'' {{div col|colwidth=25em}} *1997: [[John Toner|John L. Toner]] *1998: [[Doug Dickey]] *1999: [[Jake Crouthamel]] and [[Davey Nelson]]* *2000: [[Frank Broyles]] *2001: [[Mike Lude|Milo R. "Mike" Lude]] *2002: [[Bill Byrne (athletic director)|Bill Byrne]] *2003: [[Andy Geiger]] and [[John Clune]]* *2004: [[Vince Dooley]] *2005: [[Jack Lengyel]] *2006: [[DeLoss Dodds]] *2007: [[Jeremy Foley]] *2008: [[Gene Smith (athletic director)|Gene Smith]] *2009: [[Jim Weaver (athletic director)|Jim Weaver]] *2010: [[Robert Mulcahy]] *2011: vacated<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cbssports.com/mcc/blogs/entry/24156338/33207706 | title=National Football Foundation vacates AD award | publisher=CBSSports.com | first=Adam | last=Jacobi | date=2009-11-11 | accessdate=2011-11-09}}</ref> *2012: [[Mal Moore]] *2013: [[Joe Castiglione (athletic director)|Joe Castiglione]] *2014: [[Kevin White (athletic director)|Kevin White]] {{div col end}}
==Chris Schenkel Award== Named in honor of broadcaster [[Chris Schenkel]], the Chris Schenkel Award is given annually to distinctive individuals in broadcasting with ties to a university.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kleinpeter|first1=Jim|title=LSU's Jim Hawthorne wins Chris Schenkel Award|url=http://www.nola.com/lsu/index.ssf/2015/05/lsu_jim_hawthorne_chris_schenk.html|accessdate=June 26, 2017|work=The Times-Picayune|date=May 27, 2015}}</ref>
==Poll== {{main|FWAA-NFF Grantland Rice Super 16 Poll}} Beginning in [[2014 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2014]], 10 members of the NFF will vote in a new poll in partnership with the [[Football Writers Association of America]]. It is called the [[FWAA-NFF Grantland Rice Super 16 Poll]].
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|https://footballfoundation.org}}

The '''Oakbank Easter Racing Carnival''' is a [[horse-racing]] meeting held over two days by the Oakbank Racing Club at the [[Oakbank Racecourse]] located in the [[Adelaide Hills]] in [[South Australia]]. The carnival is a mixture of flat and jumping races with between two and four jumps races on day one and two feature jumping races on day two.
Day one is held on Easter Saturday and is one of the highest attended race days in Australia. The Von Doussa Steeplechase (named after founder [[Alfred von Doussa]]) takes place on day one and is a preliminary to the [[Great Eastern Steeplechase]] held on Easter Monday. A "classic" hurdle race takes place on Monday as does the feature flat race, the Onkaparinga Cup.
The meeting is conducted by the Oakbank Racing Club and is popular with families and groups. Although ostensibly a horse race meeting, Oakbank is an event in itself with carnival rides, picnics and other activities. Many families camp for the whole weekend in the paddocks adjacent to the track, and some have done so all their lives.
Patrons travelled by train from Adelaide to nearby [[Balhannah railway station]], {{convert|2|miles}} from the course, from 1884. When the [[Mount Pleasant railway line]] opened in 1918, a platform was constructed adjacent to the course, permitting special race trains to run direct to the course the following Easter. The line to Mount Pleasant closed on 3 March 1963, thus the race trains ran no more.<ref>'''''The Oakbank Race Trains''''' Callaghan, W.H. [[Australian Railway History|Australian Railway Historical Society Bulletin]], August, 1995 pp211-221</ref>

{{Infobox football club | clubname = PIA FC| image = [[File:Pakistan Intl Airlines logo.png|180px|PIA FC Logo]]| fullname = Pakistan International Airlines
Football Club | nickname = The Airliners | founded = {{Start date and age|1958}} | ground = [[KPT Stadium]], [[Karachi]] | capacity = 15,000 | chairman = Mehdi Changezi | mgrtitle = Head Coach | manager = Shamim Khan | league = [[Pakistan Premier League]] | season = [[2014–15 Pakistan Premier League|2014–15]] | position = Pakistan Premier League, 4th |pattern_la1= _shoulder_stripes_black_stripes |pattern_b1=_shoulder_stripes_black_stripes |pattern_ra1= _shoulder_stripes_black_stripes |pattern_sh1=_adidasblack |pattern_so1=_3_stripes_black |leftarm1=FFFFFF |body1=FFFFFF |rightarm1=FFFFFF |shorts1=FFFFFF |socks1=FFFFFF| pattern_la2= _shoulder_stripes_white_stripes |pattern_b2= _shoulder_stripes_white_stripes |pattern_ra2= _shoulder_stripes_white_stripes |pattern_sh2=_adidaswhite |pattern_so2=_3_stripes_white |leftarm2=1d1e1f |body2=1d1e1f |rightarm2=1d1e1f |shorts2=1d1e1f |socks2=1d1e1f | }} '''PIA F.C.''' are a [[Pakistan]]i football club who play in the [[Pakistan Premier League]]. Founded in 1958 and based in [[Karachi]], the [[Pakistan International Airlines]] affiliated team are the most successful Pakistani football club, winning the national championship a record 9 times. They competed in the [[2016 PFF Cup]]. Their first championship came in 1971 when thy beat Karachi. They defended their title in 1972 when they held off Peshawar White. Their third title came in the first of the two 1975 seasons, defeating provincial side Punjab A. In 1976 they retained their title, holding off a challenge from [[Pakistan Railways FC]]. PIA were defending champions in 1978, after there being no football 1977 due to martial law, but they continued to dominate Pakistani football and beat Sindh Red to take the championship for a fifth time. They defeated PAF FC in 1981 to win their sixth title. They had to wait 8 years for their next title win, SGP FC were the team beaten in 1989(2). In the 1992/93 they won their 8th title when PIA beat [[Pakistan Army FC]]. In the 1997(2) season, PIA fought off tough competition from ABL FC to win their 9th national championship. PIA were elected to PPL for the 2007/08 season without needing promotion when the PPL expanded. ==Achievements== *'''[[List of Pakistan football champions|National Football League]]/[[Pakistan Premier League]]: 9''' :: 1971–72, 1972–73, 1975–76, 1977–78, 1978–79, 1981–82, 1989–90 (II), 1992–93, 1997–98 (II) *'''[[Pakistan National Football Challenge Cup]]: 1''' :: 1984 ==Performance in AFC competitions== *'''[[Asian Club Championship]]: 2 appearances''' ::[[Asian Club Championship 1986|1986]]: Qualifying Stage ::[[Asian Club Championship 1991|1991]]: Qualifying Stage *'''[[Asian Cup Winners Cup]]: 2 appearances''' ::[[Asian Cup Winners Cup 1993|1992/93]]: withdrew in First Round ::[[Asian Cup Winners Cup 1999|1998/99]]: withdrew in First Round ==External links== * [http://www.piac.com.pk/ PIA site] {{Pakistan Premier League}} {{Pakistan International Airlines}} [[Category:Football clubs in Pakistan]] [[Category:Sport in Karachi]] [[Category:Pakistan International Airlines]] [[Category:1958 establishments in Pakistan]] {{Pakistan-footyclub-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Malay name|Shafie|Effendy}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Shafie Effendy | fullname = Mohammad Shafie bin Haji Mohammad Efenddy | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1995|8|4|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Brunei]] | height = {{convert|1.66|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[DPMM FC]] | clubnumber = 17 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Brunei Sports School|Sports School]] | years1 = 2010–2011 | caps1 = | goals1 = | clubs1 = [[Brunei Youth Team]] | years2 = 2014 | caps2 = | goals2 = | clubs2 = [[IKLS FC]] | years3 = 2015–2016 | caps3 = | goals3 = 8| clubs3 = [[Tabuan Muda]] | years4 = 2017–2018 | caps4 = | goals4 =11 | clubs4 = [[Indera SC]] | years5 = 2018– | caps5 = 11| goals5 = 0| clubs5 = [[DPMM FC]] | nationalyears1= 2011 | nationalcaps1= | nationalgoals1= | nationalteam1= [[Brunei national under-18 football team|Brunei U18]] | nationalyears2= 2012 | nationalcaps2= 4 | nationalgoals2= 0 | nationalteam2= [[Brunei national under-21 football team|Brunei U21]] | nationalyears3= 2013 | nationalcaps3= 3 | nationalgoals3= 0 | nationalteam3= [[Brunei national under-19 football team|Brunei U19]] | nationalyears4= 2013– | nationalcaps4= 15 | nationalgoals4= 0 | nationalteam4= [[Brunei national under-23 football team|Brunei U23]] | nationalyears5= 2015– | nationalcaps5= 5 | nationalgoals5= 1 | nationalteam5= [[Brunei national football team|Brunei]] | club-update = 1 October 2018 | ntupdate = 3 September 2018 }}
'''Mohammad Shafie bin Haji Mohammad Efenddy''' (born 4 August 1995) is a [[Brunei]]an international [[football]]er who plays for [[DPMM FC]] and the [[Brunei national football team]].<ref>{{cite web |title=DPMM FC players join training|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2016/10/05/dpmm-fc-players-join-training|date=5 October 2016|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> Adept at playing on [[Winger (association football)|either flank]] or as a [[Striker (association football)|striker]], he is one of the stars of Bruneian football ever since being selected to his first international tournament at the age of 16.<ref name=hbt>{{cite web |title=U-18 footballers demolish Pakistan|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2011/09/05/u-18-footballers-demolish-pakistan|date=5 September 2011|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=20 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Battered but still standing|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports/2013/11/29/battered-still-standing|date=29 November 2013|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
==Club career== At club level, Shafie played for [[Tabuan Muda]], a league team that was formed by the [[National Football Association of Brunei Darussalam|NFABD]] to prepare for international competitions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Md Syahmi powers Tabuan Muda|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2016/04/25/md-syahmi-powers-tabuan-muda|date=25 April 2016|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> They finished fifth in the [[2015 Brunei Super League|2015]] and [[2016 Brunei Super League|2016]] seasons of the [[Brunei Super League]].<ref>{{cite web|title=DST PREMIER LEAGUE 2016 STANDINGS|url=http://nfabd.org/schedules/dst-premierleague-2016-standings.htm|date=|publisher=[[National Football Association of Brunei Darussalam]]|accessdate=18 October 2016}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He previously played for the team's predecessor [[Brunei Youth Team]] in 2011, which were the league team of the Brunei under-16s in 2010.<ref>{{cite web |title=Good start for Kilanas|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2011/03/26/good-start-kilanas|date=26 March 2011|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=20 October 2016}}</ref> He moved to [[Indera SC]] for the [[2017 Brunei Super League|2017 season]]. He scored his first two goals for Indera on 10 September against [[Menglait FC]] which finished 4–0.
On 26 September 2017, Shafie scored a hattrick in the 6–0 victory over [[Najip I-Team]].<ref>{{cite web |title=27/09/2017 DST Super League|url=http://www.rtbnews.rtb.gov.bn/Lists/News/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=3778|date=27 September 2017|publisher=''[[Radio Television Brunei|Radio Televisyen Brunei]]''|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> He contributed a total of 11 goals for Indera who finished third in the league.<ref>{{cite web |title=MS ABDB win DST Super League|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/ms-abdb-win-dst-super-league/|date=11 February 2018|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref>
He signed for professional club [[DPMM FC]] of the [[Singapore Premier League]] on 13 February 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=DPMM FC sign new S League squad|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/dpmm-fc-sign-new-s-league-squad/|date=14 February 2018|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=12 March 2018}}</ref> He made his debut on 24 May in a 1–1 draw against [[Young Lions FC|Young Lions]]as a 77th-minute substitute, providing the assist for [[Adi Said]]'s equalising goal three minutes from time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsportsasia.com/football/asian-football/singapore-football/890446/ikhsan-fandi-wonder-goal-gives-young-lions-draw-brunei-dpmm/|title=Ikhsan Fandi wonder goal gives Young Lions 1-1 draw against DPMM|publisher=[[Fox Sports Asia]]|date=23 May 2018|accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Shafie has been playing exclusively with the national team setup ever since graduating from Brunei's [[Brunei Sports School|Sports School]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Sports School thrash Temburong |url=http://www.bt.com.bn/local_sport/2009/05/16/sports_school_thrash_temburong|date=16 May 2009|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> He was a member of the [[Brunei national under-21 football team|Brunei under-21]] side that was triumphant on home soil at the [[2012 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]], starting three games out of six.<ref name=hbt />
A year later, Shafie travelled to [[Thailand]] with the [[Brunei national under-19 football team|Brunei under-19s]] for the [[2014 AFC U-19 Championship qualification]], where they lost all three games.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nat'l U-19s set for AFC meet|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2013/10/06/natl-u-19s-set-afc-meet|date=6 October 2013|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> A similar story happened with the [[Brunei national under-23 football team|under-23s]] at the [[Football at the 2013 Southeast Asian Games|27th SEA Games football tournament]] in [[Myanmar]] two months later, where Shafie only played twice.<ref>{{cite web |title=South East Asian Games 2013 (Nay Pyi Taw)|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sea2013.html|date=18 June 2015|publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
Shafie missed out on the [[2014 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]] but returned with the under-23s for the [[2016 AFC U-23 Championship qualification]] held in [[Indonesia]] in late March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=U-23s set for AFC tourney|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2015/02/04/u-23s-set-afc-tourney|date=4 February 2015|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418150440/http://bt.com.bn/sports-national/2015/02/04/u-23s-set-afc-tourney#|archive-date=18 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Scoreless and goalless, the same team headed for the [[Football at the 2015 Southeast Asian Games|28th SEA Games]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Manager calls for total commitment|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2015/05/26/manager-calls-total-commitment|date=26 May 2015|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923234208/http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2015/05/26/manager-calls-total-commitment#|archive-date=23 September 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Shafie was ever-present although the Young Wasps lost all five of their games.<ref>{{cite web |title=Brunei go down to M’sia|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/frontpage-sports-national/2015/06/09/brunei-go-down-m%E2%80%99sia|date=9 June 2015|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
Shafie made his full international debut on 3 November 2015 versus [[Cambodia national football team|Cambodia]] in a friendly match that finished 6-1 against Brunei.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cambodia put six goals past Brunei in friendly|url=http://borneobulletin.com.bn/cambodia-put-six-goals-past-brunei-in-friendly/|date=4 November 2015|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=18 October 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019005621/http://borneobulletin.com.bn/cambodia-put-six-goals-past-brunei-in-friendly/#|archive-date=19 October 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was selected for the [[2016 AFF Suzuki Cup qualification]] matches held in [[Cambodia]] in October. He started the first game against [[Timor-Leste national football team|Timor-Leste]] and scored the winner in a 2–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brunei off to winning start|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2016/10/16/brunei-winning-start|date=16 October 2016|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=18 October 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027131120/http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2016/10/16/brunei-winning-start|archivedate=27 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In July 2017, Shafie captained the under-23s for the [[2018 AFC U-23 Championship qualification]] that took place in [[Yangon]], [[Myanmar]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Brunei end AFC U-23 C’Ship qualifiers with loss to Singapore|url=https://www.brusports.com/2017/07/24/brunei-end-afc-u-23-cship-qualifiers-with-loss-to-singapore/|date=24 July 2017|publisher=BruSports News|accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref> The Young Wasps lost all three games. The same story happened at the [[2017 Southeast Asian Games|29th SEA Games]] held in [[Malaysia]] a month later, where ever-present Shafie and compatriots suffered four defeats out of four.<ref>{{cite web |title=National football team end SEA Games campaign|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/national-football-team-end-sea-games-campaign/|date=24 August 2017|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref>
Shafie was selected for the national team's [[2018 AFF Championship qualification|2018 AFF Suzuki Cup qualification]] matches against [[Timor-Leste national football team|Timor-Leste]] in early September.<ref>{{cite web |title=Minister urges national team to make impact at AFF Suzuki Cup qualifier|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/minister-urges-national-team-to-make-impact-at-aff-suzuki-cup-qualifier/|date=30 August 2018|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> He played the first 45 minutes in a 3–1 defeat away from home in the first leg in [[Kuala Lumpur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxsportsasia.com/football/aff-suzuki-cup-football/935614/timor-leste-a-step-closer-to-reaching-aff-suzuki-cup/|title=Timor Leste a step closer to reaching AFF Suzuki Cup|publisher=[[Fox Sports Asia]]|date=2 September 2018|accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> Brunei were knocked out 2–3 on aggregate.<ref>{{cite web |title=Brunei win 1-0 against Timor Leste but miss out on AFF final round|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/brunei-win-1-0-against-timor-leste-but-miss-out-on-aff-final-round/|date=9 September 2018|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref>

Competition |- | 1. || 15 October 2016 || [[Olympic Stadium (Phnom Penh)|Olympic Stadium]], [[Phnom Penh]], [[Cambodia]] || {{fb|Timor-Leste}} || '''2'''–1 || 2–1 || [[2016 AFF Suzuki Cup qualification]] |}

revision.text:
[[Image:Snow Arena.JPG|thumb|300px|right|Druskininkai Snow Arena]] The '''Snow Arena''' is an [[indoor ski slope]] in [[Druskininkai]], [[Lithuania]]. It was opened on August 26, 2011.
It is one of the biggest indoor skiing slopes in the world, with the slope length of 460 m, width 50 m and height difference of 65.65 m and 150 m beginner slope. The indoor ski area is divided into two segments: [[terrain park]] and ski slope. A seasonal outdoor route of 640 m is also available when the average outdoor temperatures fall below +5°C.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.snowarena.lt/lt/uzsiemimai/trasos |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917075430/http://www.snowarena.lt/lt/uzsiemimai/trasos |archivedate=2010-09-17 |df= }}</ref>
Snow at Snow Arena is made by using [[PowderStar]] Series technology. Water and air are the only ingredients of the [[snow]] with no chemical or bacteriological additives used. The interior temperature of the hall, which is open all year round, is kept at a constant −2 to −4 °C (28.4 to 24.8 °F).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.snowarena.lt/en/apie_mus |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210114456/http://www.snowarena.lt/en/apie_mus |archivedate=2014-02-10 |df= }}</ref>
There are two ski lifts in the Snow Arena: a [[platter lift]] and a [[chair lift]]. There is also a [[Magic carpet (ski lift)]] for the beginner slope. Snow Arena offers ski rentals and lessons with the skiing school established at the arena, offers a wide range of programs for all abilities and offers group bookings for schools and businesses. It also has a small store that sells gloves, helmets and socks and offers a range of off-snow services, including four restaurants and two licensed bars.
It cost about €31 million to build this arena.
== Notable visitors ==
President of the Republic of Lithuania [[Dalia Grybauskaite]] opened Snow Arena in August 2011.<ref>http://www.15min.lt/gallery/show/Druskininku-sniego-arena-oficialiai-atidaryta-19419?p=24</ref>
Members of the Italian National Skiing Team [[Denise Karbon]], [[Manuela Mölgg]] and Sabrina Franchini coached by Livio Magoni were training for the World Cup at Snow Arena in November 2013.<ref>http://www.sportas.info/naujienos/18954-italu_zvaigzdes_liejo_prakaita_druskininkuose.html</ref>

{{Infobox film | name = Somewhere in Georgia | image = Somewhere in Georgia.jpg | image_size = | caption = | director = George Ridgwel | producer = | writer = [[Grantland Rice]]
[[Lillian Case Russell]] (scenario) | starring = [[Ty Cobb]] | cinematography = Walter Arthur | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1917|06}} | runtime = 30 minutes | country = United States | language = Silent film
[[English language|English]] intertitles | budget = }} '''''Somewhere in Georgia''''' is a [[1917 in film|1917]] [[silent film]], starring baseball great [[Ty Cobb]]. It was based on a short story by sports columnist [[Grantland Rice]]. ==Plot== Cobb stars as a small-town Georgian bank clerk with a talent for baseball. When he's signed to play with the Detroit Tigers, Cobb is forced to leave his sweetheart ([[Elsie McLeod]]) behind, whereupon a crooked bank cashier sets his sights on the girl. Upon learning that Cobb has briefly returned home to play an exhibition game with his old team, the cashier arranges for Our Hero to be kidnapped. Breaking loose from his bonds, Cobb beats up all of his captors and shows up at the ball field just in time to win the game for the home team. == Cast (in credits order)== *Ty Cobb ... Himself - Ty Cobb *[[Elsie MacLeod]] ... The Banker's Daughter *William Corbett (as Will Corbett) *Harry Fisher *Edward Boulden (as Eddie Boulden) *Ned Burton == Survival status == No prints of this film are known to survive.{{cite web |url=http://memory.loc.gov/diglib/ihas/loc.mbrs.sfdb.9372/default.html |title=Somewhere in Georgia |publisher=[[Library of Congress]] |website=Silent Film Survival Database |accessdate=October 25, 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0158971|Somewhere in Georgia}} [[Category:1917 films]] [[Category:1910s drama films]] [[Category:1910s short films]] [[Category:1910s sports films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:American silent short films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:Ty Cobb]] {{1910s-short-drama-film-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Use by sport */ edit NBA timeout rules
revision.text:
A '''television timeout''' (alternately '''TV timeout''' or '''media timeout''') is a break in a televised live event for the purpose of [[television]] broadcasting. This allows commercial broadcasters to take an [[television commercial|advertising break]], or issue their required hourly [[station identification]], without causing viewers to miss part of the action.
Programs making use of timeouts are usually [[Broadcasting of sports events|live-action sporting events]]. However, other live programs occasionally make use of timeouts for advertising purposes, such as the [[Eurovision Song Contest]].
==Use by sport== * [[American football]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]): The [[National Football League]] requires twenty commercial breaks per game, with ten in each half. (Exceptions to this are overtime periods, which have none.) These breaks run either a minute, or two minutes in length. Of the ten commercial breaks per half, two are mandatory: at the end of the first or third quarter, and at the two-minute warning for the end of the half. The remaining eight breaks are optional.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/25/business/media/25iht-espn.html |title=ESPN Positions Itself to Take on Europe |author=Samual Apt |newspaper=[[The New York Times International Edition|The International Herald Tribune]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=April 16, 2018}}</ref> The timeouts can be applied after [[field goal (football)|field goal]] tries, conversion attempts for both [[conversion (gridiron football)|one]] and [[two-point conversion|two]] points following [[touchdown]]s, changes in possession either by [[Punt (gridiron football)|punts]] or [[turnover (football)|turnovers]], and [[kickoff (American football)|kickoffs]] (except for the ones that start each half, or are within the last five minutes). The breaks are also called during stoppages due to injury, [[instant replay in American and Canadian football|instant replay challenges]], when either of the participating teams uses one of its set of timeouts, and if the network needs to catch up on its commercial advertisement schedule. The arrangement for [[college football]] contests is the same, except for the absence of the two-minute warning. * [[Baseball]]: No formal television timeout, but the interval between the end of a half-[[Inning (baseball)|inning]] is set between two and three minutes for televised games, and during pitching changes that happen in the middle of an inning for the pitcher to warm up. * [[Basketball]] ** [[College basketball|College]] men: At the first [[dead ball]] after 4-minute intervals (beyond the 16:00, 12:00, 8:00 and 4:00 minute mark of each half).<ref name=Voepel>{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/womens-college-basketball/story/_/id/9259849/ncaa-women-basketball-panel-looks-add-10-second-backcourt-rule |title=Panel recommends 10-second rule |first=Mechelle |last=Voepel |publisher=''[[ESPN.com]]'' |date=May 9, 2013 |accessdate=May 16, 2013}}</ref> Additionally, the first 30-second team timeout in the second half is expanded to a television timeout.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} If free throws are to be shot, a timeout is taken first.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} Effective with the [[2015–16 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|2015–16 season]], when a team calls a timeout within the 30-second window before the next scheduled TV timeout break, the called timeout takes the place of the scheduled TV timeout.<ref name="2015 NCAA men's changes">{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/13037928/ncaa-announces-rule-changes-2015-16-including-30-second-shot-clock-fewer-outs |title=Shorter shot clock, fewer timeouts among changes coming in 2015-16 |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=June 8, 2015 |accessdate=June 9, 2015}}</ref> A similar rule in the NBA is used when a 20-second timeout is called but a team's mandatory timeout point has been reached.<ref name=Voepel/> ** College women and FIBA: Media timeouts are taken at the first dead ball after the 5:00 mark in each quarter. Any called timeout before the 5-minute mark of a quarter becomes the media timeout. Organisers have the option in FIBA play to implement a television timeout at the next dead ball following the same point.<ref name="2015 NCAA women's changes">{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/womens-college-basketball/story/_/id/13038918/ncaa-approves-change-four-quarters-women-basketball |title=NCAA panel approves women's basketball rules changes |agency=Associated Press |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=June 8, 2015 |accessdate=June 9, 2015}}</ref> ** [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: There must be two timeouts in each quarter. In each quarter, if no team has called a timeout before the 6:59 mark, a timeout is charged to the home team, and if no subsequent timeout is taken prior to the 2:59 mark, a timeout is charged to the team not previously charged with a timeout. The first and second timeouts in each quarter are two minutes 45 seconds for locally televised games, and three minutes 15 seconds for nationally televised games. Other timeouts in a quarter are one minute 15 seconds in length. <ref>{{cite web |title=NBA Rule Book 2017{{endash}}2018 |url=https://turnernbahangtime.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/2017-18-nba-rule-book.pdf |page=22 |publisher=[[National Basketball Association]] |accessdate=May 27, 2018}}</ref> * [[Bowling]]: Varies.{{vague|date=July 2012}} * [[Cricket]]: Generally at the end of some [[overs]] as the field switches around, when a [[wicket]] falls, during drinks breaks and during intervals. In the [[2009 Indian Premier League|2009 season]] of the [[Indian Premier League]] of [[Twenty20]] [[cricket]], the halfway point of each [[innings]] contained a seven-and-a-half minute stoppage of play, two-thirds of which were devoted to advertising time.<ref name=guardian-ipltimeout>{{cite news|title=Indian Premier League introduces compulsory time-outs during matches|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/apr/16/indian-premier-league-cricket|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=4 April 2013|location=London|first=Lawrence|last=Booth|date=16 April 2009}}</ref> After complaints by viewers and players (criticizing its use as an extended commercial break, and for breaking the flow of the game), these breaks were replaced in the following year by two compulsory "strategic timeouts" of two-and-a-half minutes per innings. One must be taken by the bowling team between the 6th to 10th overs, and the batting team between the 11th to 16th overs.<ref name=ipl3-timeout>{{cite news|title=IPL 3 to start on March 12 in Hyderabad|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-08-11/top-stories/28156697_1_ipl-chairman-lalit-modi-ipl-ii-deccan-chargers|publisher=The Times of India|accessdate=4 April 2013|date=11 August 2009}}</ref><ref name=cricketcountry-strategic>{{cite web|title="Strategic time out" to rake in money|url=http://www.cricketcountry.com/cricket-articles/-Strategic-time-out-to-rake-in-money/2896|publisher=Cricket Country|accessdate=4 April 2013}}</ref> * [[Curling]]: at the conclusion of each end. The game generally resumes before the commercial break ends, so when the broadcast comes back on a few rocks will have already been thrown.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} * [[Ice hockey]] ** [[National Hockey League|NHL]]: Commercial time-outs are taken after 4-minute intervals at the first stoppages of play after the 14:00, 10:00 and 6:00 marks in each period when both teams are at even strength. However, there are no commercial time-outs after a goal, after an icing, during a power-play, during the last 30 seconds of the first and second period or last two minutes of the third period. Also, there must be at least one minute of play between commercial time-outs and an effort must be done to identify the situations where a video review might happen in order to NOT go into a commercial time-out. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nhlofficials.com/articles/view/55 |title=Week 20 - Need a Break? |website=www.nhlofficials.com |date=February 23, 2015 |access-date=April 16, 2018}}</ref> During [[NHL outdoor games|outdoor games]], a hard TV timeout is called at the 10:00 mark of the third period, and play is immediately stopped (as they need to change ends of the ice to ensure fairness). Additionally there are no timeouts, commercial or team, granted during a shootout. Due to these restrictions, it is possible that not all of the scheduled breaks are taken, in which case sometimes a network will take a timeout at the conclusion of the game to make up for it before signing off on the broadcast.<ref>{{citation | url=http://www.kuklaskorner.com/index.php/rbh/comments/nhl_to_implement_another_rule_change_for_icing/ | title=NHL to implement another rule change for icing | publisher=kuklaskorner.com | date=November 23, 2008}}</ref> During [[overtime (ice hockey)|overtime]], television timeouts are taken only in the following situations: ***In the preseason and the regular season, between the end of the overtime period and the beginning of the shootout. No television timeouts are taken during the overtime period. ***In the postseason, at the first stoppage of play after the halfway point in the overtime period. *[[Motorsports]]: Most races are unable to accommodate television timeouts, but certain events, such as the NASCAR [[Camping World Truck Series]], events are structured with a safety car after 20 minutes of green flag action to help inexperienced drivers acclimate themselves with pit stops (full green flag pit stops are discouraged in order to help younger drivers gain experience with live pit stops in a more controlled environment). In order to alleviate the lack of television timeout periods, technology such as [[Side-By-Side (graphic)|Side-By-Side]] has been introduced. During the Sprint All-Star Race, commercials are only taken between periods after the pit stop, or during safety car situations. * [[Tennis]]: during the break after odd-numbered games when players change ends.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} * [[Volleyball]] and [[beach volleyball]]: in volleyball games governed by [[Fédération Internationale de Volleyball|FIVB]], television timeouts are referred to as [[Technical time-out (volleyball)|technical time-outs]] and occur during each non-[[tie-break]]ing set.<ref>{{cite web| title = Official Volleyball Rules|year= 2005| url = http://www.fivb.org/en/volleyball/Rules/Rules.htm | work = [http://www.fivb.org/ FIVB.org] | publisher= [[Fédération Internationale de Volleyball]] | accessdate = 2008-08-20}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Television Timeout}} [[Category:Television advertising|Timeout]] [[Category:Sports television|Timeout]] [[Category:Terminology used in multiple sports]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox ski jumping hill | hill_name = Trampolino Olimpico Italia | nickname = Italia | image = [[Image:Olympic-Ski-Jumping-hill-Cortina.JPG|300px]] | caption = | location = | coordinates = | city = [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]] | country = [[Italy]] | opened = 1923 | renovated = 1955 | expanded = | closed = 1990 | demolished = | size = | k-spot = K-90 | hill size = NH 92 (LH 1956) | hill record = 92.0 m Roger Ruud {{flagicon|Norway}}
1981 WC | capacity = 40.000
(+10.000 hill stands) | championships = | olympics = [[Ski jumping at the 1956 Winter Olympics|1956]] | world championships = [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1927|1927]] | world cup = [[1979–80 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|1979]] 1981, 1982, 1984, 1985 | national championships = }} [[Image:Trampolino Cortina.JPG|thumb|200px|left|Olympic Ski Jumping Hill ([[Cortina d'Ampezzo]])]] '''Trampolino Olimpico Italia''' is a [[ski jump]]ing hill (K90), built in 1955 in [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]], [[Italy]]. It was the site of the [[ski jumping]], [[Nordic combination|Nordic combined]] (K90/15.0) and team events for the [[1956 Winter Olympics]]. The Nordic combined event used a shorter in-run to allow average jumps between 60 and 70 meters while the upper starting points on the in-run were calculated to allow jumps of 70 to 80 meters. The 1956 profile had a safety limit of 14.5 m beyond the critical point of 72 m. (transition from the landing slope curve to the out-run begins at a distance of 86.5 m).{{cite web|title=Cortina 1956 Olympic Winter Games Report - (PDF) page 134, 135|url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1956/orw1956.pdf|publisher=la84.org|accessdate=December 4, 2013|language=Italian}} Among many national and international competitions starting with the [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1927|1927 World Championships]], was the inauguration of the [[FIS Ski Jumping World Cup]] in [[1979–80 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|1979]]. Since the venue lost its FIS-certification in 1990,{{cite web|title=Ski Jumping Hill Archive - Cortina d'Ampezzo|url=http://www.skisprungschanzen.com/EN/Ski+Jumps/ITA-Italy/Cortina+d%60Ampezzo/0330/|publisher=skisprungschanzen.com|accessdate=December 2, 2013}} the installation lies dormant. In its day, the Cortina Ski Jumping hill was regarded as one of the most innovative and still today as one of the most architecturally beautiful examples still in existence. The stadium holds a maximum of 40,000 spectators in the arena and an additional 10.000 in the stands on each side of the hill. It was featured in a scene in the 1981 James Bond film ''[[For Your Eyes Only (film)|For Your Eyes Only]]''. ==History== 2.5 km (2 mi) from Cortina, near Zuel, the "Italia" ski jumping hill (Trampolino Olimpico Italia) began its life in 1923 as the "Franchetti" Jump. That year, the Dolomites Sports Club, with a grant from Baron Carlo Franchetti and funds from the hotel owners of Cortina, constructed the first ski jumping installation with a modest wooden in-run platform which allowed jumps up to 40 meters. Timeline: *1923 - 40 meter hill built with a modest wooden in-run structure. *1924 - Ski jumpers Greising and Schatz of Innsbruck (Austria), established the first hill record of 42 m. *1926 - First alterations to increase the length of the jump to 52 m. New hill record by Tore Edmann (Sweden) of 54 m. *1927 - The first Ski Jumping World Championships at Cortina. *1939 - Completely demolished due to new F.I.S. technical requirements for the up-coming 1941 F.I.S contests. *1940 - New construction with a 48 m. in-run tower, permitting jumps of 75 m. The new venue is named "Italia". *1941 - F.I.S. World Championships. First hill record by Sepp Weiler (Germany) of 76 m. *1952 - Last hill record by Ossi Laaksonen (Finland) of 78 m. *1955 - Again completely demolished and re-built the same year due to the technical requirements for the up-coming 1956 Olympic games. *1956 - The VII Olympic Winter Games see the most advanced modern ski jumping installation of the era. Hill record by Antti Hyvärinen of 84 m. *1979 - First round of the inaugural Ski Jumping World Cup (revisited in 1981, 1982, 1984 and 1985). *1981 - Last hill record of the Olympic Italia by Roger Ruud (Norway) of 92 m. *1990 - The "Italia" loses its F.I.S. certification due to financial constraints. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1956/orw1956.pdf 1956 Winter Olympics official report.] pp. 137–55. {{en icon}} & {{it icon}} *[http://www.skisprungschanzen.com/index.htm?/ita/ita_cortina.htm Skisprungschanzen.com profile of Cortina.] {{de icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120106224345/http://www.worldstadiums.com/europe/countries/italy/veneto.shtml Stadium information] *[http://www.dolomiti.org/ita/cortina/cser/gis/trampolino/ 1956 Olympics information] {{1956 Winter Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues Nordic combined}} {{Olympic venues in ski jumping}} {{coord|46.511301|12.146738|display=t|type:landmark}} [[Category:Venues of the 1956 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in Italy]] [[Category:Ski jumping venues in Italy]] [[Category:Olympic Nordic combined venues]] [[Category:Olympic ski jumping venues]] {{Italy-sports-venue-stub}} {{skijumping-venue-stub}}

[[File:Årjängstravet.jpg|thumb|439x439px|Årjäng Big Sprinter Race]]'''Årjängstravet''' is a horse racing track for [[harness racing]], located in [[Årjäng]], Värmland County, Sweden. Årjängstravet is known as "the most beautiful harness racing course in Sweden".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arjangstravet.se/|title=Årjängstravet {{!}} Sveriges vackraste travbana|website=www.arjangstravet.se|language=sv-SE|access-date=2017-10-23}}</ref> Årjängstravet arranges about 20 horse racing events in a year.
== History == The course was built in 1936. Eight men transformed a mire to a fully usable kilometer harness racing course, using shovels, wheelbarrows and 3-5 North Swedish horses they completed the building of the track in ten weeks. The men behind the work were: Ossian Jonasson, Gunnar Jonasson, Reidar Jonasson, Cato Kristiansson, Ragnar Alfredsson, Sven Alfredsson, Tyko Kylén and Georg Nilsson.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Från istrav till v65|last=Magnusson|first=Per O|publisher=A. Svanqvist & son, Årjäng|year=1986|isbn=|location=Årjäng|pages=20}}</ref> The premier use of the racetrack was on 30 September, in the same year.
== Major events == Årjäng Big Sprinter Race.
